narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project 'req_8f03ec1fc5' will generate multi-modal datasets from youth participants, including demographic and clinical datasets, behavioral and cognitive assessments, neuroimaging and/or physiological measures, derived variables, and documentation (protocols, data dictionary, README). The estimated amount of scientific data expected to be generated is substantial, with neurobiological data representing the largest portion of storage.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected data types will be preserved and shared through the NIMH Data Archive (NDA) to facilitate secondary research use and maximize the potential for scientific discovery. The rationale for sharing these data is to enable researchers to investigate social communication and neurodevelopmental profiles in youth with autism, compare them to typically developing peers, and explore the underlying neural mechanisms.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible: 
Data dictionary
Protocols for treatment and data collection instruments
README files describing the datasets and their contents
NDA GUID elements collected for submission to the NIMH Data Archive (NDA)

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools, software, and/or code are needed to access or manipulate shared scientific data. Specifically, 
FMRIB Software Library (FSL) for neuroimaging analysis
MATLAB for physiological signal processing
R for statistical analysis of behavioral and cognitive assessments
These tools can be accessed through their respective websites or repositories.

Common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata to enable interoperability of datasets and resources. The project will apply the 
NIMH Data Archive (NDA) data standards for neurodevelopmental disorder research
Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) for organizing and describing neuroimaging data
These data standards will be applied by using standardized templates for data collection, adhering to established protocols for data processing, and utilizing validated tools for data analysis.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from the project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), a repository designated by NIH for storing and sharing data related to mental health research.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be findable and identifiable via a persistent unique identifier, such as a DOI or an NDA Collection ID, and through standard indexing tools like the NDA Data Dictionary.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available to other users no later than the time of an associated publication or end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data will be available for at least 10 years after the initial release to allow for secondary research use and validation of findings.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer:
Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data include informed consent restrictions, privacy and confidentiality protections, and limitations imposed by the IRB-approved protocol. Specifically, 
Broad data sharing consent/assent has been obtained from participants
Data will be de-identified to protect participant privacy
Access may be controlled for sensitive information

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will be controlled through the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), which requires users to register and agree to terms of use before accessing shared data.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer:
To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, 
Data will be de-identified
Certificates of Confidentiality will be obtained as necessary
IRB-approved protocols will guide data collection and sharing practices

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer:
Compliance with this Plan will be monitored and managed by the Principal Investigators (PIs) and the research team. The PIs will ensure that 
All shared data are properly de-identified
Documentation is accurate and up-to-date
Access to controlled data is granted only to authorized users
The oversight frequency will be at least bi-annually, with adjustments as needed based on project progress and feedback from stakeholders.
